Headline: NZ Telecom Corp Meets Min To Accelerate Split Plans -Sources
Story: By Rachel Pannett   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     WELLINGTON (Dow Jones)--Telecom Corp. of New Zealand Ltd. (TEL.NZ) met with Telecommunications Minister David Cunliffe Monday in a bid to fast track discussions on an operational split being imposed on the company, people familiar with the talks said.   One person told Dow Jones Newswires that several law makers, including Cunliffe, met with Telecom management as part of the ongoing talks relating to a planned three-way split into network, wholesale and retail divisions.   "There (was) a meeting. It's not just with Cunliffe, it's several ministers and (Telecom) senior management. It's part of the operational separation discussion," the person said.   The participants are understood to have included officials from the Ministry of Economic Development, which provides policy advice on the regulatory environment for the telecommunications sector.   Cunliffe, who as Telecommunications Minister is charged with implementing the split along with introducing legislation that will force Telecom to open its fixed-line local network to rivals later this year, declined to comment Monday on whether the talks took place.   "I do not normally comment on my meetings," Cunliffe said, adding: "the Government has an open door policy and I regularly consult with industry."   Telecom declined to comment on the matter.   The split and other changes are part of the Telecommunications Amendment Bill, passed in December last year. The bill is designed to weaken Telecom's monopoly grip on the local phone network and increase the country's uptake of high-speed Internet services.   Telecom, New Zealand's biggest listed company, brokered the operational separation with law makers in November in order to avoid an even more onerous structural split, which would have led to separate ownership and stock listings for each of its units.   But local media reports suggest progress since then has been slow, distracting Telecom from preparing to meet the increased competition the changes will likely bring.   "It's a huge weight on the business trying to do this at the same time as trying to monitor technology shifts, and invest in this and that," the person close to the talks said. "It takes a lot of resources on something that is quite logistically challenging."   He added, however, that "there is an understanding that it doesn't get done overnight."   Telecom, a former state-owned monopoly, controls just over 80% of New Zealand's telecommunications market, estimated at NZ$8 billion a year. The company estimates increased competition will reduce its share of the retail market from 84% as at Dec. 31, to between 60% and 70% by 2012.   The company is currently mulling how to use the proceeds of last month's NZ$2.24 billion sale of its Yellow Pages directories business.   Investors are hoping for a substantial capital return, although analysts caution that over NZ$1 billion may be earmarked for capital expenditure, including funding its NZ$360 million purchase of Australia-based junior telco PowerTel Ltd. (PWT.AU), recapitalizing its joint venture with Hutchison Australia (HTA.AU) in the H3GA mobile network, and a potential upgrade of its CDMA mobile network in New Zealand.   Telecom is expected to update the market on its capital spending plans at its fiscal third quarter result early next month.     -By Rachel Pannett, Dow Jones Newswires; 64-4-471-5990; rachel.pannett@dowjones.com   -Edited by David Bottomley     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 23:58 ET (03:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : AT&T In Negotiations For Investment In Telecom Italia
Story: SAN ANTONIO, April 1 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- AT&T Inc. (NYSE: T) today said it is in negotiations for a potential indirect investment in Telecom Italia S.p.A. The proposal is for AT&T to purchase a one-third stake in Olimpia S.p.A., a holding company with approximately 18 percent of Telecom Italia's ordinary shares, subject to satisfactory completion of AT&T's due diligence, agreement on other terms of the transaction, and satisfaction of other conditions.  As part of these negotiations, America Movil, S.A.B. de C.V. (AMX) also is considering an investment for one-third of the shares of Olimpia. AT&T's investment is contingent on America Movil's investment.     AT&T is in negotiations on the potential investment to acquire the interest from Pirelli & C S.p.A., which owns 80 percent of Olimpia.  Olimpia holds only Telecom Italia assets.     The valuation of the stakes in Olimpia which are the object of the possible sale would be based on a price per Telecom Italia share equal to euro 2.82, minus the net debt of Olimpia on the closing date of the transaction, subject to the satisfaction of the terms of the proposal.     As a global telecom leader in wireless, broadband and IP networks with customers in 137 countries, AT&T is continually reviewing opportunities that will help it serve the company's growing global customer base.  AT&T believes its potential investment in Olimpia would provide Telecom Italia with a strategic partner with whom it can share best practices and pursue joint interests.     AT&T has proven itself to be a capable, committed partner in its international investments, partnering with local owners and managers, and working with governments to bring the latest in telecommunications networks, products and services to consumers and businesses. Examples of this include AT&T's 17-year partnership with Telmex, whose successful collaboration has helped deliver one of the most modern telecommunications networks in North America, as well as AT&T's investment in South Africa, which resulted in a mutually beneficial relationship that helped consumers and business customers alike.     Telecom Italia is one of Europe's largest and best-run communications service providers with a market capitalization of about euro 40 billion ($53.4 billion). It has 24 million landline, 57.9 million mobile and 8.6 million broadband connections, including broadband interests in the Netherlands, France and Germany, and wireless in Brazil.     AT&T, which Forbes magazine recognized as "Company of the Year" in 2006, is an industry leader in convergence, integrating networks and applications to deliver services to the "three screens" that matter most to consumers: the TV, personal computer and wireless device. AT&T plans to invest about $18 billion in capital in 2007 to strengthen its wireless, wireline and international networks.     Note: This AT&T release and other news announcements are available as part of an RSS feed at www.att.com/rss.        About AT&T     AT&T Inc. is a premier communications holding company. Its subsidiaries and affiliates, AT&T operating companies, are the providers of AT&T services in the United States and around the world. Among their offerings are the world's most advanced IP-based business communications services and the nation's leading wireless, high speed Internet access, and voice services. As part of its three-screen integration strategy, AT&T is expanding video entertainment offerings to include next-generation television services such as AT&T U-verse(SM) TV. In domestic markets, AT&T is known for the directory publishing and advertising sales leadership of its Yellow Pages and YELLOWPAGES.COM organizations, and the AT&T brand is licensed to innovators in such fields as communications equipment.  Additional information about AT&T Inc. and the products and services provided by AT&T subsidiaries and affiliates is available at www.att.com.        AT&T and the AT&T logo are trademarks of AT&T Knowledge Ventures.    SOURCE  AT&T Inc.       /CONTACT: U.S. - Ashley Blaker for AT&T, +1-210-351-5036, ashley.blaker@att.com, Europe - Niall Hickey, +44-771-577-1451, niall.hickey@att.com; Italy - Marco Palocci for AT&T, +39-335-5648280, mpalocci@brunswickgroup.com      /Web site: http://www.att.com      /Web site: http://www.att.com/rss     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 15:57 ET (19:57 GMT)

Headline: Carlyle Group To Hire Senior Coca-Cola Exec For Asia Ops - FT
Story: SINGAPORE (Dow Jones)--Carlyle Group is expected to announce the hiring of Coca-Cola Co.'s (KO) most senior executive in Asia to spearhead regional investments across consumer-related businesses, the Financial Times reported on its Web site Monday.   The recruitment of Patrick Siewert, Coca-Cola's chief operating officer for Asia-Pacific, is the second such hiring in recent weeks by the U.S. private equity firm, the report said.   It recently recruited Herman Chang, former director of Asia Pacific operations for Delphi, to focus on industrial companies in the region.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com       (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 20:29 ET (00:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Nepal Former Communist Rebels Sworn In As New Govt Members
Story: KATMANDU, Nepal (AP)--Six former communist rebels were sworn in as ministers and a junior minister in Nepal's new government on Sunday as part of a landmark peace pact that ended a decade-long insurgency in this Himalayan nation.   Five former Maoists were appointed ministers, while a sixth was given a junior minister portfolio in the new government to be headed by Girija Prasad Koirala.   The swearing in ceremony was broadcast live on national television.   Earlier, Nepal's Parliament re-elected Koirala as prime minister of the new government.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 04:51 ET (08:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(4/2) Breakingviews.com: Is China's ICBC Overrated?
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)   Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, which reports its earnings tomorrow, is vying with Bank of America for the honor of being the world's second-largest bank by stock-market value, behind Citigroup. ICBC has just nosed ahead in this extraordinarily tight race. But that means ICBC is probably one of the world's most overvalued banks -- and a Chinese stock-mania bellwether.   Since its initial public offering last October, ICBC stock has risen around 70% on the Shanghai exchange. The Chinese bank's market capitalization of $228 billion, at Friday's close, means it trades at 3.3 times its book value and 28 times its forecast 2007 earnings, according to data provider JCF Factset. By comparison, Bank of America, which boasts a similar return on equity, is a steal. The U.S. bank trades at around half the book value and about one-third the earnings multiple of ICBC. Bank of America's dividend yield of 4.4% is also twice as generous.   Not only is Bank of America a better value, it's also decades ahead of ICBC in business strategy. Commercial loans account for only a quarter of its lending and 11% of its assets. Its net interest income from these loans is only 6% of revenues. Like most large banks nowadays, Bank of America makes most of its money from consumer lending, and from fees and trading.   By comparison, ICBC resembles a U.S. money-center bank from half a century ago. Seventy percent of its loans were made to domestic companies as of last June, and net interest income from these accounted for 46% of its operating revenues. Typical of its transactions is the five billion yuan ($646 million) loan it made last Wednesday to the state-owned Zhanjiang Port Group. Western banks still make large corporate loans, but they do so in groups, and after taking their fees they pass them on as quickly as possible. ICBC kept the entire loan on its books.   China may be the future, but ICBC looks like the past. Of course, it will adapt as Chinese financial conditions change. But there will be tough challenges ahead, including problems with nonperforming loans. The Chinese banking giant is unlikely to retain its global No. 2 slot for long.     Conflicted Buyouts     Management-led buyouts are fraught with conflicts of interest. Corporate insiders, after all, know far more about the state of their businesses than anyone else. That's why special committees are set up to run the bidding process when senior executives want to take their companies private. These groups of independent directors are the best protection shareholders have against being short-changed. Unfortunately, they're not always up the job.   Take the case of Houston-based freight company EGL, which founder Jim Crane is trying to take private. Two weeks ago, EGL's directors agreed to Mr. Crane's offer to acquire the business for $38 per share. Not only is this price around 25% below where the stock was trading last summer, but it's the same price that private-equity firm Apollo Management had expressed a willingness to pay. And Apollo says it might have bid more if it had been given fuller access to EGL's books and management.   To make matters worse, the special committee has agreed to pay a breakup fee of $30 million, or about 1.5% of the value of the company, if anyone trumps Mr. Crane's bid. Half of that fee goes directly to Mr. Crane. New York-based Apollo has responded by suing the independent directors for "blatant breaches of fiduciary duty." Lawyers working on behalf of the special committee couldn't be reached to explain its decisions. Mr. Crane declined to comment.   Breakup fees generally serve a useful purpose. They both encourage potential buyers to make serious offers, while compensating them for their expenses if their bid is topped. But the case of EGL highlights how they may fail to add shareholder value in the case of management buyouts. After, all the odds are already stacked against outsiders. Special committees shouldn't make matters worse.   -- Martin Hutchinson and Lauren Silva   ---   This column is written by breakingviews.com, an online financial commentary site.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 19:55 ET (23:55 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(4/2) Tribune Appears To Be Nearing A Deal With Zell
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Sarah Ellison   After months of drama in its boardroom and declining performance at its newspapers, Tribune Co. late yesterday appeared to be firming up a deal to sell itself to Chicago real-estate tycoon Sam Zell, according to people familiar with the matter.   Over the weekend, Tribune's special committee of the board reviewed competing offers from Mr. Zell and a joint bid from Los Angeles businessmen Eli Broad and Ron Burkle. Both offers propose taking the company private using an employee stock ownership plan.   To be sure, it was possible the board could decide to further extend its self-imposed deadline of March 31 and take more time to reach a decision. And final important details remained to be ironed out. But people close to the discussions said that Mr. Zell's offer -- which is valued at $33 a share -- was preferred. Tribune's shares traded up 58 cents Friday to $32.11 on the New York Stock Exchange.   The offer from Messrs. Broad and Burkle, while valued Tribune at $34 a share, is less certain and would take more time to complete, a strike against it in the minds of members of the special committee of Tribune's board, who have been laboring over the sale process for six months. But with many twists and turns in the auction process, people close to the situation cautioned that a last-minute turn was still possible.   Representatives from the Broad-Burkle camp appeared resigned over the weekend to Mr. Zell's likely success. "They just don't want to do (a deal) with us," said a person familiar with the duo's thinking, referring to Tribune's board. The special committee had asked for additional information from Messrs. Broad and Burkle Friday, but the joint proposal isn't as far along as Mr. Zell's, this person said. It would take additional time to firm up a deal with the California businessmen. That uncertainty is likely to give Mr. Zell the edge in closing a deal.   A spokesman for Tribune and a spokeswoman for Mr. Zell declined to comment.   Mr. Zell is expected to put in less than $300 million in equity, a fraction of the company's total value of about $7.9 billion, not counting Tribune's existing $4.5 billion in debt. The deal will unfold in two steps, according to a person familiar with its structure. In the first step, Mr. Zell will invest his equity and receive convertible preferred stock in Tribune. Then, Tribune would borrow money and pay out about $17.50 a share to shareholders. If approved, the company would be taken private, with shareholders receiving an additional payout and the majority of the company being held by an employee stock ownership plan, which would roll future contributions to employee 401(k) funds into the ESOP, effectively providing capital for the buyout without increasing Tribune's debt.   Should the deal go through, Mr. Zell, who entered the bidding for Tribune at the eleventh hour and is known for picking up out-of-favor businesses that scare away most investors, will end up as chairman of the company, which owns newspapers including the Los Angeles Times and the Chicago Tribune, and a string of TV stations. He has said his interest in the company is financial, and not to promote any political agenda. Messrs. Broad and Burkle, for their part, both talked about their strong emotional ties to the Los Angeles Times and their desire to protect the paper.   The sale of the 160-year-old media conglomerate would be the latest sign of the retrenchment of the newspaper industry, which is undergoing an historic shift. Today, newspapers are under direct assault as never before, mostly from the Internet, which is siphoning off readers and advertisers. Investor confidence has plummeted.   Should a sale go through, it would come after a particularly punishing year for newspapers. From the moment Tribune first revealed that its major shareholder -- the Chandler family -- was in open rebellion against company management, Tribune and other newspaper companies have revealed a consistently declining picture of their business. The auction of the company, sparked last summer by the Chandlers' complaints about Tribune's stock price, has been stymied by deterioration in the newspaper business.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 19:44 ET (23:44 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: BP Shareholders To Query Yukos Bid
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--British oil company BP (BP.LN) will face questions from at least two of its top 20 shareholders over its role in the auction of the remaining assets of bankrupt Russian company Yukos (YUKO.RS), The Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported Sunday.   Shareholders are planning to express concern that BP's reputation could suffer as a result of TNK-BP (TNBP.RS), the joint venture company owned by Alfa Access Renova and BP, bidding for a 9.44% stake in Yukos, the paper said.   TNK-BP dropped out of the auction shortly after making the bid leaving Russia's Rosneft (ROSN.RS) the winning bidder.   A BP spokeswoman said the company is not aware of anyone approaching the company directly on this issue.     Newspaper Web site: www.telegraph.co.uk/     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 07:48 ET (11:48 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Pirelli In Exclusive Talks With AT&T,America Movil
Story: (This updates an item published at 1829 GMT with further details, comments from shareholders, Italy Telecommunication minister)     MILAN (Dow Jones)--The board of Italian tires-to-telecom group Pirelli & C. Spa (PC.MI) Sunday entered exclusive talks with U.S. telecommunication operator AT&T (T) and Mexican mobile phone operator America Movil (AMX) to sell 60% of its stake in Italian unlisted holding company Olimpia SpA, the company said Sunday.   This would pave the way for the two telecommunication operators to become the two single largest shareholders of Italy's largest telecom group Telecom Italia SpA (TI).   Pirelli indirectly controls an 18% interest in Telecom Italia through its 80% stake in Olimpia. Italian unlisted holding company Sintonia, controlled by the Benetton family, owns the remaining 20% of Olimpia.   AT&T and America Movil valued Telecom Italia at EUR2.82 per share minus the EUR2.8 billion net debt of Olimpia, the same people said, noting however that the price is subject to due diligence by the two companies and all the conditions of the contract.   "The deal is worth around EUR2.7 billion, a person familiar with the matter said Sunday. "The dividend that Olimpia will receive from Telecom Italia EUR0.14 per share, or EUR336 million and more than compensates the financial charges of the first three months of the year." Olimpia's debt will be cut by at least EUR200 million.   Later Sunday Italy's Telecommunication Minister Paolo Gentiloni Sunday said he is "deeply worried" about the news Pirelli entered exclusive talks AT&T (T) and America Movil (AMX) adding that "the government would watch the situation closely."   Gentiloni said he and the government had been informed only Sunday afternoon that Pirelli's board would have held an extraordinary meeting to evaluate the offers.   In November, Pirelli wrote down the value of its Olimpia stake by EUR2.1 billion, valuing Telecom Italia shares at EUR3 each, still well above Telecom Italia current market price.   According to the terms of the agreement the right of first refusal on Olimpia shares is recognized to Italian merchant bank Mediobanca SpA (MB.MI) and Assicurazioni Generali SpA (G.MI). Olimpia shares control of Telecom Italia with investment bank Mediobanca SpA, which owns 1.5%, and insurer Assicurazioni Generali SpA, which has a 3.7% stake.   If they take up those rights, AT&T and America Movil will each get an indemnification equal to EUR16 million.   AT&T and America Movil have also said they would offer a put option to Pirelli and Sintonia on their remaining Olimpia stake and their Telecom Italia holdings for a year after any deal.   In the case the deal is completed by April 30, the share capital of Olimpia will be equally subdivided into three quotas among AT&T, América Móvil and the current shareholders, Pirelli & C. and Sintonia.    AT&T said in an emailed statement it believes its potential investment in Olimpia would provide Telecom Italia with a strategic partner with whom it can share best practices and pursue joint interests.   AT&T was advised by JPMorgan while Pirelli has been advised by Credit Suisse.     -By Sabrina Cohen, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 347 3563 463; sabrina.cohen@dowjones.com   (Giada Zampano contributed to the report)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 18:01 ET (22:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Gemini Announces 2006 Year-End Reserves Information And Activity Update>GNI.T
Story: VANCOUVER, March 30 /CNW/ - Gemini Energy Corp. (GNI-TSX) is pleased to report the results of its year-end reserves report prepared by Netherland, Sewell Associates, Inc. as at December 31, 2006. The reserves information summarized below is available in greater detail in National Instrument 51-101 format within the Company's Annual Information Form available on SEDAR at www.sedar.com.    Unless otherwise noted the currencies referred to are in United States dollars ("US$").          <<      HIGHLIGHTS        -   Year-end 2006 net Proved plus Probable reserves increased 11% to          149.2 billion cubic feet of natural gas equivalent (Bcfe) compared to          123.6 Bcfe at year-end 2005, resulting in a Proved plus Probable          reserves replacement of 813%        -   Year-end 2006 net Proved reserves increased 11% to 89.6 Bcfe compared          to 80.1 Bcfe at year-end 2005, resulting in a Proved reserves          replacement of 298%        -   2006 net production totaled 3.02 Bcf natural gas and 22.6 thousand          barrels of condensate, or 3.15 Bcfe, compared to 3.53 Bcfe produced          in 2004, a decrease of 11%      >>      RESERVES    The December 31, 2006 reserve report was prepared utilizing the methodology and definitions as set out under National Instrument 51-101 ("NI 51-101") and standards contained in the Canadian Oil and Gas Evaluation Handbook. Under NI 51-101, proved reserve assignments are based on a 90 percent probability that total quantities recovered will equal or exceed proved reserve estimates. Proved plus probable reserves are the expected case where there is an equal chance that the Proved plus Probable reserves will be higher or lower than estimated.    The year-end reserves for 2006 and 2005 presented include company working interests before and net after royalties and using forecast and constant price and cost assumptions. Where amounts and volumes are expressed on a gas equivalent basis, liquids volumes have been converted to cubic feet of gas at a ratio of 6,000 cubic feet of gas per barrel (6 Mcf/bbl). A conversion ratio of one bbl to six Mcf is based on an energy equivalency conversion method primarily applicable at the burner tip and does not represent equivalency at the wellhead.          <<       Summary of Company Interest Oil and Gas Reserves - Headline: UPDATE:Itochu Inks Contract To Buy Stakes In 15 US Gas Fields
Story: (Adds details)     TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Japanese trading house Itochu Corp. (8001.TO) said Monday it signed a contract with U.S. gas developer Range Resources Ltd.  Friday to acquire stakes in 15 gas fields in the Gulf of Mexico.   Under the contract, Itochu will acquire two subsidiaries of Range Resources that hold the stakes in the fields.   An Itochu spokesman declined to discuss the investment value.   The Nikkei reported in its Sunday morning edition that Itochu plans to invest a total of about Y100 billion on natural gas development in the U.S. over three years through 2010, and the acquisition is the first step.   In 2007, Itochu intends to spend roughly Y25 billion on gas development in the U.S, said the report.   The stakes awarded to the Japanese trading house range from 10% to 49%, and all of the gas fields have already started production, with total natural gas output equivalent to 2,300 barrels a day of crude oil, according to the report.   The Japanese company plans to sell the gas to local power utilities, chemical manufacturers and other firms equipped with their own power generation facilities through a network of pipelines laid across the country that will be connected to its gas production facilities, said The Nikkei, without elaborating.     -By Mari Iwata, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; mari.iwata@dowjones.com   -Edited by George Bernard     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 21:02 ET (01:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : IDC Reports 2006 Results>IDL.T
Story: CALGARY, March 30 /CNW/ - Imaging Dynamics Company Ltd. (IDC or the Company) (TSX: IDL) a global supplier in the high growth digital radiography (DR) equipment market, today reported financial results for the fourth quarter and the full year ended December 31, 2006. For the 2006 year, IDC reported a loss of $0.14 per share before one time write downs, for a full-year loss of $0.25 per share after write downs on revenues of $39,030,402. For the fourth quarter, the Company reported a loss of $0.07 per share before one-time write downs, on revenues of $12,533, 867 and a loss of $0.19 per share after write downs.    Commenting on the results of 2006, Darryl Stein, President & CEO of IDC said, "In 2006, the Company focused its efforts on top line sales growth, market share capture and channel development. Significant investments were made in new products, new geographies and new markets. These investments added over 50 new channel partners globally and growth through new products into the veterinary and chiropractic markets. IDC has invested into building a global distribution network, and a broad array of products to meet the growing demand for digital technology.    The Company has experienced exceptional growth over the last two years - revenues growing by over 550% in that period - with a strategy that has taken more time, money and resources than was anticipated, negatively affecting the Company's financial performance with respect to expenses and write downs.    The introduction of new products to displace earlier models equated to a higher rate of inventory obsolescence than in the past, and an increased learning curve for the Company's technical personnel and integration efforts.    The focus in 2007 is to reap the benefits of investments made in 2006. The Company's operations and infrastructure are being revamped to more effectively support the sales engine we have created. We started restructuring the operations of the Company in late Q3 of 2006. New management and staff were hired; new processes and new tools are being implemented, including the implementation of a new Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system. In January 2007 the financial modules were implemented, and the testing and validation of the manufacturing, inventory, purchase order and sales order modules has been completed and will go live during April 2007. This provides full financial and operational connectivity with a direct impact on the efficiencies and profitability of the organization.    The internal restructuring and implementation efforts have been arduous but essential to the long-term health of the business. We made a deliberate decision to give the Company time to complete implementing all of the restructuring efforts and as such revenues booked for Q1 will be soft, but for all the right reasons. I am confident that within 60 days IDC will not only be positioned, but capable of delivering on the significant opportunities ahead of us."          <<      Imaging Dynamics Company Ltd. Headline: Francisco Partners Invests $100M in Retail FX Platform
Story: By Isabelle Lindenmayer     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Francisco Partners has invested $100 million in online currency trading provider FX Solutions.   The deal, to be announced Monday, comes on the heels of a slew of similar deals, in which venture capital firms have bought into the growing number of retail online currency trading companies.   FX Solutions, based in Saddle River, N.J., is one of the expanding number of companies that allows retail investors to tap into the global currency market, which boasts daily turnover of roughly $2 trillion a day and allows even novices to place relatively large bets by leveraging their investments.   Robert Cortright, co-chief operating officer at FX Solutions, said in a statement that the company plans to use the capital to develop additional trading options for its clients at a more rapid clip.   Competition in the online retail trading space is heating up as the number of retail foreign exchange firms has jumped to about 37 from three five years ago, according to the National Futures Association, a self-regulatory body that also serves as a watchdog for futures trading.   That growth has been helped along by companies like Francisco Partners - a Menlo Park, Calif.-based firm focused on technology-related investments - which are willing to back such ventures.   "We were impressed with the technological depth of FX Solutions' trading platform," David Golob, managing director at Francisco Partners, said in a press release. Neither company would comment further.       Latest In A String Of Deals     In the past year, three such deals have made headlines in the retail currency trading platform industry.   In April, VantagePoint Venture Partners announced it had invested $40 million in foreign exchange trading platform GAIN Capital Group Inc.   The investment was twice the amount of capital invested in GAIN's three previous capitalization rounds, which netted the company approximately $20 million from investors including Tudor Investments, Edison Ventures, Cross Atlantic Capital Partners, and Blue Rock Capital.   A month later, private equity firm General Atlantic invested $127 million in Saxo Bank, which specializes in Internet-based technology systems for trading foreign exchange, foreign exchange options, equities and futures options.   In July, Technology Crossover Ventures bought a minority stake in FXall, the electronic foreign-exchange trading platform, for $77.5 million.   Private equity investors are not the only ones trying to make headway into this market, however. A number of banks have also recently launched their own retail trading platforms - usually with the help of an already existing provider - in an attempt to cater to the growing number of retail traders.   Last May, for example, Deutsche Bank (DB) launched DBFX, a Web site that offers retail customers 24-hour online margin currency trading, and ABN Amro (ABN) rolled out a new trading platform last summer aimed at retail currency, equity, fixed income and commodity traders.       Explosive Growth Has Drawbacks     Although interest in online retail currency trading has clearly grown, so too, have regulatory problems.   Just over a week ago, a U.S. District Court judge froze the assets of Forefront Investments Corp., an online retail trading provider also known as CFG Trader, after the company failed to meet minimum net capital requirements.   The action came after it was discovered that the company had liabilities of $8 million but assets of just $6.8 million, putting its 3,800 day-trader customers at risk of not being able to get their money back.   Rules require such firms to maintain assets of $1 million more than their liabilities. The NFA is considering bumping up the minimal capital requirements to better protect customers, who are often gambling with their savings without full knowledge of the risks associated with currency trading.   Indeed, more than 25,000 investors have been defrauded in currency-enforcement cases pursued by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission since Congress gave the regulator authority over a small slice of currency trading in the U.S. in late 2000.     -By Isabelle Lindenmayer, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-5063; Isabelle.Lindenmayer@dowjones.com   (Dan Molinski in New York contributed to this report.)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 18:00 ET (22:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Moody's Reviews Sp Ausnet Group's Rtgs For Possible Cut>SPN.AU
Story: The following is a press release from Moody's Investors Service:    Moody's Reviews Sp Ausnet Group's Ratings For Possible Downgrade     Sydney, April 02, 2007 -- Moody's Investors Service has today placed the ratings of the SP AusNet Group on review for possible downgrade.   "The review follows the announcement that SP AusNet is in discussion with Singapore Power regarding the Alinta assets to be acquired by Singapore Power," says Clement Chong, a Moody's VP/Senior Analyst.   Singapore Power is a member of a consortium, which has been set up to acquire Alinta Ltd under a proposed scheme of arrangement. The credit rating of Singapore Power has been placed under review following the announcement of the proposed scheme of arrangement involving Alinta.   "Under Moody's Joint Default Analysis approach for government-related issuers, a downward movement in the rating of Singapore Power, the support provider for SP AusNet, could have a negative impact on the ratings of SP AusNet and its wholly-owned subsidiaries," adds Chong.   "In addition, the review reflects the uncertainty surrounding the ownership structure of the Alinta assets, and the potential impact on SP AusNet's credit profile should it emerge as the ultimate owner," says Chong.   The ratings of SP AusNet's wholly-owned subsidiaries are also under review for possible downgrade given their linkage to the parent's credit profile.   The ratings under review are:   SP AusNet - A1 Corporate Family Rating   SPI Electricity & Gas Australia Holdings Pty Ltd - A1 Senior Unsecured Rating   SPI Australia Holdings (Partnership) Ltd Ptnrship - A1 Senior Unsecured Rating   SPI Electricity Pty Ltd - A1 Senior Unsecured Rating   SPI PowerNet Pty Ltd - A1 Issuer Rating   SPI Australia Finance Pty Ltd - A1 Senior Unsecured Rating   The review will focus on the resolution of the above-mentioned issues.   SP AusNet is a listed infrastructure fund based in Melbourne, Australia. It owns [1] SPI Australia Group -- which owns Victoria's electricity and gas distribution networks -- and [2] SPI PowerNet Pty Ltd -- which owns Victoria's electricity transmission network.   SPI Australia Group comprises three rated entities of SPI Electricity & Gas Australia Holdings Pty Ltd, SPI Australia Holdings (Partnership) Ltd Partnership, SPI Electricity Pty Ltd.   SPI Australia Finance Pty Ltd is the financing vehicle for SPI PowerNet.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 19:57 ET (23:57 GMT)

Headline: UK PRESS: British Airways In Talks With TPG On Iberia Bid
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--British Airways (BAB) is in talks with private equity company Texas Pacific Group on a potential GBP2.3 billion joint takeover bid for Spanish airline Iberia, The Independent on Sunday newspaper said.   BA owns a 10% stake in Iberia and is seeking advice from investment bank UBS on whether to sell its holding or join the bidding process, it said.   Separately, the Sunday Times and Observer newspapers said Sunday that BA has pulled its two directors from the board of Iberia in case of a conflict of interest.   A BA spokesman said that the company was unable to confirm it was in talks with TBG.     Newspaper Web site: www.independent.co.uk   Newspaper Web site: www.timesonline.co.uk   Newspaper Web site: www.guardian.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 09:19 ET (13:19 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Deepwell Energy Services Trust -3-
Story: Upon review of Deepwell's opportunities for growth, the Trustees concluded that retention of more cash to provide capital for growth would be most appropriate. A reduction in the cash distribution will provide greater financial flexibility to exploit Deepwell's high-return growth opportunities.     ------------------------------------------------------------------------    Investing activities     ------------------------------------------------------------------------    Net cash used in investing activities during the year was $49,215,940.    Business acquisitions    On April 27 the Trust purchased all of the issued and outstanding shares of Deepwell Disposal Services Inc. in exchange for 356,000 Class B Trust Units valued at $3,560,000. The Trust incurred transaction costs of $57,068.    On April 28, 2006, the Trust purchased the oilfield waste management assets of Producers Disposal Services Ltd. and Rycroft Disposal Well Inc. ("PDS" and "Rycroft" respectively) for cash consideration of $42,754,509. The Trust also incurred transaction costs of $241,279. The Trust acquired all of the assets of PDS and Rycroft, excluding security deposits held by the EUB. The Trust assumed the asset retirement obligations of PDS and Rycroft; however the Trust assumed only those operating liabilities accruing to PDS and Rycroft subsequent to March 31, 2006. The Trust also did not assume any bank indebtedness or amounts due to affiliates.    Capital expenditures    Excluding investment on the original acquisition, (which is detailed above) the Trusts' capital expenditures for purchase of property and equipment for the year were $6,808,967.    In the third quarter of 2006, a new pipeline from the Grande Cache facility to the disposal well was installed at a cost of approximately $1,290,000.    To increase capacity at Grande Cache, a second disposal well was placed into operation by stimulating an out-of-service disposal well at a cost of approximately $1,900,000. The well was put into service in late September and some productivity increases were realized in the fourth quarter, although the positive impact was mitigated by the operational downtime at Grande Cache in the fourth quarter. In March, 2007, Deepwell received EUB approval to increase wellhead pressure at this well, and further increases in injection rate are expected as a result.    A solids treatment pad was installed at Grande Cache in the fourth quarter at a cost of approximately $390,000. The pad allows solids to be treated, such that landfill disposal costs can be significantly reduced. The pad was damaged in the December 7, 2006 fire, but should be repaired and placed back into service in the second quarter of 2007.    Approximately $350,000 was invested in computers, furniture and other head office equipment upon the establishment of the Trust's head office location in August, 2006.    Approximately $170,000 was invested in preliminary costs for acquisition and conversion of a second disposal well at Rycroft. An application was made in 2006 to the EUB for approval to add the second well into service, and approval was granted in March, 2007. The existing well at Rycroft was stimulated in June, 2006 at a cost of approximately $260,000, and the well's performance has improved substantially since that time.    Approximately $730,000 was invested in preparation of the well, and application to the EUB for approval of Deepwell's planned facility at Claresholm., Alberta. An additional $30,000 was invested in costs related to other future facilities.    The remaining cost relate primarily to improvements of drainage and retention ponds at the facilities, new injection pumps, new tanks, mobile equipment.     ------------------------------------------------------------------------    Unitholders' equity     ------------------------------------------------------------------------    On April 27, 2006, the Trust completed a private placement offering of 4,000,000 Class B Trust units at $10 per unit, for total gross proceed of $40,000,000 less agents' commission of $2,400,000 and other expenses of $669,133. The net proceeds of $36,930,367 were used to complete the acquisition of PDS and Rycroft. An additional 356,000 Class B Trust units were issued as purchase consideration for Deepwell Disposal Services Inc.    Pursuant to the Trust's prospectus dated August 18, 2006, the Trust exchanged all outstanding Class B Trust Units on a one for one basis for Units of Deepwell Energy Services Trust. Subsequent to the exchange of Units, the Trust received approval to list the Units for trading on the TSX, and the Units commenced trading on the TSX on August 24, 2006. As of the March 28, 2007, the Trust had 4,356,000 Units outstanding.    Trust unit option plan    The Trust has established a unit option plan for trustees, directors, officers, employees and consultants. The Trust recognizes unit-based compensation expense in the consolidated statement of income for all unit options granted based upon their fair value at the time of grant. The fair value is determined using an accepted option pricing model, with total compensation expense recognized over the period the options vest. Compensation expense is offset with a corresponding increase to contributed surplus. Consideration paid by the option-holder upon the exercise of the options, together with the amount previously recognized in contributed surplus, is recognized as an increase in Unitholders' capital.    As at December 31, 2006 a total of 314,500 options issued pursuant to the Trust incentive stock option plan ("Option Plan") were outstanding at an average exercise price of $10.01. All of these units were issued during the period and remain outstanding at December 31, 2006. No options are exercisable at December 31, 2006, and the weighted average contractual life remaining is 4.65 years. The total number of outstanding options shall not exceed 10% of the outstanding Trust Units. The options carry a five year term and vest equally over a period of three years from the date of grant. The exercise price of each option is based upon the weighted average trading price for a period prior to the date of grant. The exercise price is adjusted downwards by 100% of the amount of distributions paid on outstanding Trust Units. As at December 31, 2006, the exercise prices of outstanding options range from $9.62 to $10.26 per unit and the weighted average exercise price of granted options is $9.63 per unit.    The Trust recorded unit option compensation expense and contributed surplus of $251,432 during the period. The fair value of options issued during the period was estimated using the Black-Scholes pricing model with the following assumptions: risk free interest rate of 4.25%; volatility of 35%; life of 5 years; the impact of monthly distributions and corresponding changes in exercise price during the life of the options are assumed to be equal and offsetting, and so no provision is made in the pricing model for either factor.     ------------------------------------------------------------------------    Liquidity     ------------------------------------------------------------------------    As at December 31, 2006, the Trust had cash of $28,861. The Trust also has credit facilities in place in the aggregate of $17,500,000.    Net cash provided by financing activities for the year was $45,385,577. The Trust realized $36,930,377 in net proceeds of its private placement on April 27, 2006. At December 31, 2006, the Trust had drawn $11,500,000 million on its long term credit facility. Deferred financing costs of $95,711 were paid relating to the establishment of the Trust's credit facilities. A total of $55,841 of deferred financing costs was amortized during the period. Other financing activities include the payment of $2,949,088 in distributions to Unitholders related to the periods from April 29, 2006 to December 31, 2006.    Credit facilities    Deepwell LP established credit facilities on April 27, 2006 with a Canadian chartered bank (the "credit facilities") which consist of a $2,000,000 demand revolving operating loan and a $15,500,000 364-day extendible revolving term loan, as well as a credit card facility. As of December 31, 2006, the borrowing base for the demand revolving loan was at $1,808,000 and the amount drawn was nil. As at December 31, 2006, an aggregate of $11,500,000 was drawn on the revolving term loan.    The operating loan bears interest ranging from the lender's prime rate plus 0.125 percent to prime plus 0.625 percent depending on the rate of debt to EBITDA, with interest payable monthly. The extendible revolving facility does not require principal payments thereunder until May 31, 2007, unless otherwise extended. If extended, the facility will continue not to require the payment of principal. If not extended, the credit facility reverts to a three-year term with principal payments thereunder commencing monthly after the date such facility is not renewed.    As security for the credit facilities, Deepwell LP granted the lenders a security interest over all of its assets. In addition, each of the Trust, Deepwell Energy Services Commercial Trust and the Deepwell Energy Services Ltd. guaranteed the indebtedness of Deepwell LP under the credit facilities, with such guarantee being secured by all of the assets of each such guarantor. In respect of any proceeds resulting from enforcement of the Credit Facilities or the above-mentioned guarantees, the lenders, as creditors, will have a prior-ranking claim relative to the Unitholders.    The credit facility is subject to customary terms and conditions for borrowings of this nature, including limits on incurring additional indebtedness, granting liens or selling assets without the consent of the lender and maintenance of certain interest coverage and leverage ratios.    Interest rate risk    The operating loan and the extendible revolving term loan bear interest at a floating interest rate. Therefore, the extent that the Trust borrows under these facilities, the Trust is as risk to rising interest rates.          <<      Contractual obligations     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  April 01, 2007 10:21 ET (14:21 GMT)
